Direct conversion of ethene to isobutene was studied by combining heterogeneous catalysts for ethene dimerization and skeletal isomerization of normal butene. NiO/SiO2-Al2O3 and zeolite were simultaneously loaded to a flow reactor in separate layers, and the conversion of ethene was performed at 300 ℃. Reaction using NiO/SiO2-Al2O3 alone produced normal butene predominantly, and isobutene selectivity was low at 1 %. However, introduction of zeolite into the lower catalyst phase greatly enhanced isobutene selectivity. The crystal structure and SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of zeolite had marked influences on isobutene selectivity, and ferrierite with a moderate amount of acid sites was most effective. The activity of ferrierite was further increased by ion-exchange with metal ions such as Fe, which enhanced not only isobutene selectivity but also catalyst durability. Effects of the reaction conditions were also studied, with the optimal setup affording isobutene at a selectivity of 31 %, which is the highest selectivity reported to date. It is used to produce gasoline additives such as methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE), ethyl tert-butyl ether (ETBE), and isooctane [3]. Butyl rubber, polyethene terephthalate (PET), and methyl methacrylate are also produced from isobutene [3,4]. Currently, isobutene is produced mainly as a byproduct of the steam cracking of naphtha and the fluid catalytic cracking of crude oil [2,5]. Replacement of the feedstock of the cracking process from petroleum to shale gas or natural gas, as well as the increasing demand for isobutene, have stimulated the development of novel, sustainable processes for isobutene synthesis [6]. Proposed alternative isobutene synthesis methods include dehydration of isobutanol [4,7], dehydrogenation of isobutane [2,5], skeletal isomerization of normal butene [8,9], isobutene synthesis from ethanol [3,6] and syngas conversion to isobutene [1,10]. The dehydrogenation of isobutane to isobutene has been commercialized by CB&I Lummus (the Catofin process using a CrO x /Al2O3 catalyst) and UOP (the Oleflex process using a PtSn based catalyst) [11]. Our group is currently focused on developing a process that uses ethene oligomerization for the production of isobutene. Typically, ethene oligomerization using a homogeneous metal complex, alkyl-aluminum cocatalyst, and organic solvent is used for the production of linear α-olefins [12]. For example, IFP-SABIC Alphabutol technology that uses a Ti-based complex catalyst and an alkyl aluminum cocatalyst has been commercialized for the production of 1-butene, and the reaction proceeds at ethene conversion of 80–85 % with a selectivity for 1-butene approaching 93 % at 50–60 ℃ and 2–3 MPa [13]. Immobilization of a metal complex on metal–organic frameworks (MOF) has attracted attention recently, and catalysts showing a 1-butene selectivity exceeding 90 % have been developed [14,15]. Heterogeneous catalysts for ethene oligomerization have also been studied, and Ni-loaded solid acid catalysts (e.g., Ni-AlSBA-15 [16], Ni-AlMCM-41 [17], NiO/SiO2-Al2O3 [18]) show high catalytic activity. However, the selectivity for butene isomers (1-butene, trans/cis-2-butene, and isobutene) by ethene oligomerization over heterogeneous Ni catalysts depends on the reaction temperature and type of catalyst. It has been reported that at low temperatures (<0 ℃), 1-butene is produced with high selectivity; for example, Ni-AlMCM-41 catalyst produces 1-butene with a selectivity of 93 % within the temperature range of −30 to −15 ℃ [17]. However, with increasing reaction temperature, the selectivity for 1-butene decreases, and that of trans/cis-2-butene increases [19]. At 70–120 ℃, the selectivity for 1-butene is 10–60 %, and that of 2-butene is 35–75 % over Ni-AlMCM-36 [20], Ni-beta [21], and Ni-AlKIT-6 [22] catalysts. At even higher temperatures (i.e., 150–250 ℃), the selectivity for 2-butene exceeds 60 % over most of the catalysts and that for 1-butene decreases to less than 20 % [16,18,20,23]. In addition, the selectivity of isobutene is generally lower than 5 % over both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [24]. The only exception is over ZSM-5–based catalysts [25,26]; for example, it has been reported that the HMCM-41/ZSM-5 catalyst produces isobutene with a selectivity of 17 % at 350 ℃ [25]. However, over these ZSM-5–based catalysts, various side reactions such as alkylation, hydrogenation, cracking, and aromatization also proceed, which makes it difficult to produce isobutene selectively. Overall, it is hard to convert ethene into isobutene directly using previously reported catalysts for ethene dimerization (see Table 1 for summaries of several catalysts reported to date for ethene dimerization). As an alternative to ethene oligomerization, skeletal isomerization of normal butene to isobutene has also been studied extensively. Initially, mesoporous materials such as phosphoric acid–loaded SiO2 and halogen-modified Al2O3 were used, but they suffered from fast catalyst deactivation [27,28]. In the 1990s, the development of microporous materials with proper acidity and channel structure (i.e., 10-membered ring [MR] zeolites and molecular sieves) led to breakthroughs in this approach [29]. Various microporous materials containing a 10-MR such as ferrierite [8,9,30], SAPO-11 [31], ZSM-5 [32], HPM-1 [33], ZSM-35 [34] and ZSM-22 [35] showed high isobutene selectivity exceeding 80 % at around 400 ℃ and a high catalytic activity that lasted for > 100 h. More recently, studies led by Sievers have shown that the skeletal isomerization proceeds not inside the micropore but near the pore mouth of 10-MR and that the active site is a monoaromatic species trapped in the pore mouth that is polarized by internal Brønsted acid sites [36,37]. Here, we hypothesized that combining two kinds of catalysts, one for ethene oligomerization and one for skeletal isomerization of normal butene, would provide better direct conversion of ethene to isobutene compared with the use of each catalyst alone. NiO/SiO2-Al2O3 (Ni-SA) was used as the ethene dimerization catalyst, and various zeolite and metal oxide catalysts were used as the isomerization catalyst. The two catalysts were loaded simultaneously into a fixed-bed flow reactor in two layers, and the conversion of ethene to isobutene was tested. The effects of different combinations of catalysts, ion-exchange of the zeolite catalysts with various metal ions, and the reaction conditions on isobutene selectivity and yield were studied in detail. In short, we found that using Ni-SA with Fe-exchanged ferrierite (FER) at 300 ℃ and 0.1 MPa afforded isobutene from ethene with moderate selectivity (31 %), which is the highest value reported to date for the direct conversion of ethene to isobutene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ni-SA catalyst was prepared in a similar way to previous studies [38,39]. All chemicals used for the preparation of Ni-SA were purchased from Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemical Corporation. SA support was prepared by means of homogeneous precipitation using tetraethyl orthosilicate (95.0 +%), Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (98.0 +%), and urea (99.0 +%) at 90 °C for 2 days, followed by filtration, washing with distilled water three times, drying at 110 °C overnight, and calcination in air at 500 °C for 6 h. The Al2O3 content was 3 mol%. The amount of urea was 5 times that required for the precipitation of Al3+ ions. Ni was loaded by means of ion-exchange, which was performed three times using 1 mol L−1 Ni(NO3)2 aqueous solution (liquid-to-solid ratio, 10 mL g−1) at 70 °C for 4 h. After ion-exchange, the catalyst powder was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water three times, dried at 110 °C overnight, and calcined in air at 400 °C for 3 h. Ni-loading was 1.1 wt%. NH4-formed zeolite samples were calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h before use. The metal oxides were γ-Al2O3 (AKP-G15; Sumitomo Chemical), ZrO2 (SUR-100; Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co.), CeO2 (HS; Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co.), SiO2-Al2O3 (JRC-SAL-4; JGC Catalysts and Chemicals), SiO2-MgO (JRC-SM-2; Mizusawa Industrial Chemical), and montmorillonite (K 10; Sigma-Aldrich). The metal precursors used were Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, Cr(NO3)3·9 H2O, Mn(NO3)2·6 H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O, Co(NO3)2·6 H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O, and Ga(NO3)2·8 H2O. Ni-SA and isomerization catalyst were granulated to particles of diameter 0.35–0.71 nm and mounted into the center of quartz reactor (inner diameter 12 mm, length 28 cm) in two layers, with Ni-SA (0.25 g) on the top and the isomerization catalyst (0.25 g) on the bottom. The catalysts were calcined in a flow of N2 (20 mL min−1) at 450 °C for 1 h before reaction. Typically, the reaction was performed at 300 °C and 0.1 MPa for 40 min. Flow rates of C2H4 and N2 were 20 mL min−1 and 20 mL min−1, respectively. The reaction products were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph (GC-2014; Shimazu) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a Rt-Alumina BOND/Na2SO4 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm; Restek). The carbon mass balance of the products was within 100 ± 5 % for most of the catalysts. The catalytic reaction was repeated three times for each catalyst to confirm reproductivity (the experimental error was less than 5 %). 2.3 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured with a BELSORP MAX II (MicrotracBEL Corp.) at −196 °C. Total pore volume was calculated from the amount of nitrogen gas adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.99. Micropore volume and external specific surface area of the zeolite catalysts were calculated using the t-plot method. The pore size distribution was determined from the desorption branches of the N2 isotherms according to the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The solution used for the measurement was prepared by dissolving the catalyst powder in hydrofluoric acid at room temperature. The amounts of weak, medium-strength, strong, and total acid sites were calculated from the amount of NH3 desorption. The catalyst powder was pressed into a self-supporting wafer (diameter 1 cm, weight 10 mg), placed into a sample holder and loaded into an in situ cell. After the evacuation in vacuum at 450 °C for 1 h, the sample was cooled to 100 °C and the background was recorded. The amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were calculated from the IR bands at 1544 (Brønsted acid sites, BAS) and 1456 (Lewis acid sites, LAS) cm−1, according to the procedure reported by Emeis [40]. The products released by coke were detected by a combination of thermogravimetric analysis and mass spectrometry. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effects of isomerization catalyst addition on ethene dimerization by Ni-SA Conversion of ethene to isobutene was tested using Ni-SA (0.25 g) and FER(51) (0.25 g) catalysts, either alone or in combination, in a flowing mixture of C2H4 (20 mL min−1) and N2 (20 mL min−1) at 300 °C ( Table 2). When the reaction was performed using a Ni-SA catalyst alone, the main products were butene isomers (total selectivity, 80 %), and the rest of the products were C6 compounds (mostly hexene; selectivity, 8 %), C3 compounds (mostly propene; selectivity, 5 %), C5 compounds (mostly pentene; selectivity, 3 %), and long-chain hydrocarbons with a carbon number greater than 7 (selectivity, 1 %) (entry 1). Butene and hexene were produced by dimerization and trimerization of ethene, respectively, on the Ni sites of Ni-SA [12]. Propene and pentene were produced by cracking of hexene and octene on the acid sites of the SA support [25]. Among the butene isomers, the majority was normal butene (1-butene and cis/trans-2-butene), and isobutene selectivity was as small as 1 %, indicating that the acid sites of the SA support were not active for the skeletal isomerization of normal butene at 300 °C. Next, when the reaction was performed using FER(51) catalyst alone, the selectivity of normal butene was decreased to half of that over Ni-SA, and that of isobutene showed a marked increase from 1 % to 30 %, showing that FER(51) promoted skeletal isomerization of normal butene to isobutene (entry 2). However, the isobutene yield was only 1.3 %, since the reaction rate for ethene dimerization was slow over FER(51). When Ni was loaded on FER(51) by means of ion-exchange to accelerate ethene dimerization, the selectivity and yield of isobutene did not increase (entry 3). Combined use of Ni-SA and FER(51) on the top and bottom layers, respectively, showed higher activity than Ni-SA or FER(51) alone, and the selectivity and yield of isobutene were 26 % and 9.8 %, respectively (entry 4). In addition, the isobutene selectivity and yield over a physical mixture of Ni-SA and FER(51) were competitive with those over the unmixed catalysts (entry 5). However, when the layers were reversed and FER(51) was loaded on the top and Ni-SA on the bottom, the isobutene selectivity and yield were less than one-fifth as high as those of the alternative layering and the physical mixture (entry 6). Overall, these results indicated that normal butene formed on the Ni-SA catalyst by ethene dimerization was successfully converted to isobutene by skeletal isomerization on the FER(51) zeolite catalyst. Screening for the optimal skeletal isomerization catalyst was performed using six mesoporous materials and eight zeolite samples at 300 °C in a flowing mixture of C2H4 (20 mL min−1) and N2 (20 mL min−1). The specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of these catalysts are presented in Table 3. BET specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore size were 97–490 m2 g−1, 0.20–1.08 cm3 g−1, and 4.0–26.1 nm, respectively for the mesoporous materials (entries 1–6), and 335–692 m2 g−1, 0.18–1.02 cm3 g−1, and 1.7–7.2 nm for the zeolite samples, respectively (entries 7–14). The external specific surface area and micropore volume of the zeolite samples were 2–59 m2 g−1 and 0.13–0.81 cm3 g−1, respectively (entries 7–14). Consistent with the previous experiment, the amount of isobutene production was small over the Ni-SA catalyst alone, and the isobutene selectivity and yield were 1.0 % and 0.3 %, respectively ( Table 4, entry 1). When CeO2, ZrO2, γ-Al2O3, SiO2-MgO, or montmorillonite was loaded as the bottom layer, with Ni-SA as the top layer, the selectivity and yield of isobutene did not increase (entries 2–6). However, loading of SiO2-Al2O3 did increase the isobutene selectivity from 1.0 % to 3.4 % and the isobutene yield from 0.3 % to 1.1 % (entry 7). Overall, the addition of a zeolite was more effective than that of a mesoporous material for isobutene formation. For the zeolite catalysts Y, MOR, Beta, and ZSM-5, the catalytic reaction tests were performed at five different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios, and the results for the catalysts that showed the highest activities are shown in Table 4. Isobutene selectivity and yield increased in the order of Y < MOR < Beta < ZSM-5 < FER (entries 8–15). FER zeolite has a 10-MR channel that promotes skeletal isomerization of normal butene to isobutene [29,30,41,42], resulting in high catalytic activity for the conversion of ethene to isobutene. Also, it is well known that FER zeolite is less active for the bimolecular cracking reactions and thereby can suppress the formation of byproducts such as C3 and C5 hydrocarbons [43]. In contrast, while the addition of Y, MOR, Beta, or ZSM-5 promoted the skeletal isomerization of normal butene, it also promoted the dimerization of normal butene and the successive cracking of octene, resulting in enhanced selectivity for C3, C5, and C7 + hydrocarbons rather than isobutene. The effect of the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio was also examined for the FER zeolites; the highest isobutene selectivity and yield were obtained over FER(51), which had a moderate amount of acid sites (entries 12–15). We calculated the equilibrium conversion of ethene dimerization (2 C2H4 ↔ 1-C4H8 + Trans 2-C4H8 + Cis 2-C4H8 + Iso-C4H8) at 300 °C and 0.1 MPa using a thermodynamic calculation software HSC Chemistry (version 5.1; Outokump). The equilibrium values of C2H4 conversion exceeded 99 %, and the yields of isobutene, trans-2-butene, cis-2-butene, and 1-butene were 60.6 %, 19.6 %, 13.5 %, and 5.7 % respectively. These values were similar with the thermodynamic equilibrium of butene isomers reported by Alberty and Gehrig at 323 °C (isobutene 54.6 %, trans-2-butene 23.4 %, cis-2-butene14.4 %, 1-butene 7.6 %) [44]. However, the isobutene yield obtained using the combination of Ni-SA and FER(51) at 300 °C and 0.1 MPa (Table 4, entry 14) was much lower than the equilibrium value of the isobutene yield. Thus, further catalyst improvement was necessary, and modification of the isomerization catalyst was performed next. 3.2 Effect of metal ion loading on FER zeolite To increase the catalytic activity of FER for the skeletal isomerization of normal butene, loading of metal ions (Mg, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, or Ga) by ion-exchange onto the FER zeolite was investigated. The final loading amounts of the metal ions was 0.04–2.76 wt% for M-FER(18) and 0.01–0.29 wt% for M-FER(51), depending on the type of metal ion and the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio ( Table 5). Catalytic activity was evaluated in a flowing mixture of 1-C4H8 (20 mL min−1) and N2 (45 mL min−1) at 300 °C and 0.1 MPa using 0.20 g of catalyst. When the reaction was performed using FER(18), the main products were trans-2-butene and cis-2-butene, and the selectivity and yield of isobutene were 10.9 % and 9.1 %, respectively (Table S1, entry 1). Loading of Mg, Ni, or Cu decreased isobutene selectivity and yield, that of Zn changed neither the selectivity nor yield, and that of Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, or Ga increased them. The highest activity was obtained over Fe-FER(18). The selectivity and yield of isobutene over Fe-FER(18) were 17.4 % and 14.9 %, respectively (Table S1, entry 5). Among the ion-exchanged catalysts, the FER(51)-based catalysts were more active than the FER(18)-based ones for the skeletal isomerization of 1-butene ( Fig. 1). Fe-loaded FER(51) showed the highest isobutene selectivity and yield, and Cr-loaded FER(51) showed the second highest activities (Table S2). Metals other than Fe and Cr also increased the catalytic activity of FER(51), but the increase of catalytic activity by the metal-ion loading was smaller. The isobutene selectivity and yield over Fe-FER(51) were 24.4 % and 20.8 %, respectively, when the amount of catalyst was 0.2 g (Table S2, entry 5), but they were increased to 45.1 % and 41.3 %, respectively, when the amount of catalyst was increased to 1.0 g (Table S2, entry 11). Together, these results show that loading of metal ions is effective for promoting skeletal isomerization of 1-butene over FER zeolite at 300 °C. Next, the catalytic activity of Fe-loaded FER(18) prepared by ion-exchange was compared with that of Fe-loaded FER(18) prepared by impregnation using Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O followed by drying at 110 °C overnight and calcining at 400 °C for 3 h. The activities of the two catalysts for skeletal isomerization of trans-2-butene were examined at 300 °C. Fe-loading by impregnation did not increase the catalytic activity when the loading amount of Fe was in the range of 0.15–1.0 wt% (Table S3, entries 3–6). In contrast, Fe(0.45 wt%)-loading by ion-exchange afforded a 1.8-times higher isobutene yield compared with that over FER(18) under the same reaction conditions (entry 2). These results suggest that while FeO x particles deposited on the external surface of the FER do not contribute to the skeletal isomerization of normal butene, ion-exchanged Fe ions existing inside the FER micropores do promote the reaction. Direct conversion of ethene to isobutene was tested using the combination of Ni-SA and M-FER(51) (M = Cr, Fe, Ga) at 300 °C. Loading of these metal ions slightly increased the catalytic activity (Table 4, entries 14, 16–18). Isobutene selectivity increased from 25.8 % to 29.1–30.8 %, and iso-butene yield increased from 9.8 % to 10.7–11.3 %. The time courses of ethene conversion, isobutene selectivity, and yield showed that decreases of catalytic activity due to coke formation were largely suppressed by the loading of the metal ions by ion-exchange ( Fig. 2). These results show that ion-exchanged metal ions, especially Fe ions, not only accelerate the skeletal isomerization of normal butene but also improve the resistance of the catalyst against coke formation. Ion-exchanged metal ions may poison or limit access to the active sites of side reactions, resulting in improvements of the isobutene selectivity and catalyst lifetime. To clarify the roles of ion-exchanged metal ions, metal-loaded FER zeolites were characterized by ICP-AES, XRD, N2 adsorption, NH3-TPD and Py-FTIR. The loading amounts of metal ions measured by ICP-AES were 0.04–2.76 wt% for M-FER(18) and 0.01–0.29 wt% for M-FER(51) (Table 5). FER(18) contained a larger amount of Al ions than did FER(51), resulting in a larger amount of ion-exchanged metal ions. When the isobutene yield by skeletal isomerization of 1-butene was plotted against the loading amount of metal ions, the catalysts with low loading tended to show a high catalytic activity, indicating that highly dispersed metal species may promote skeletal isomerization of normal butene (Fig. S1). The BET specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore size of the M-FER(51) catalysts were 424–485 m2 g−1, 0.18–0.21 cm3 g−1, and 1.70–1.74 nm, respectively, which were comparable to those of the bare FER(51) catalyst (454 m2 g−1, 0.19 cm3 g−1, and 1.69 nm) within the experimental error (Table 3, entries 13, 15–23). The external specific surface area (2–5 m2 g−1) and micropore volume (0.17–0.20 cm3 g−1) of M-FER(51) were also unchanged by ion-exchange with the metal ions. These results show that loading of metal ions does not influence the micropore structure of the zeolite and by extension the diffusion of the reactants and products. XRD patterns of the FER(18) and metal-loaded FER(18) catalysts showed peaks assignable only to ferrierite zeolite (Fig. S2). The peak position of the FER(18) catalysts matched perfectly with JCPDS card No. 98–009–7919 for the ferrierite structure [45]. A broad hump was observed at 10–20° because several peaks were overlapped due to the low crystallinity of our samples. Peaks assigned to metal additives were not observed, indicating a high dispersion of metal species on the FER zeolite. NH3-TPD profiles of the FER zeolites with different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios and Fe-exchanged FER zeolites were also examined ( Fig. 3). At least three peaks centered around 200, 450–500, and 800 °C were observed in the profiles of the FER zeolites, and the intensity of these peaks tended to decrease with increasing SiO2/Al2O3 ratio. The amount of acid sites was decreased to about one-third when the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio was increased from 18 to 77 (Table S4). Ion-exchange with Fe ions did not change the NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 3). Furthermore, the NH3-TPD profiles of FER zeolite exchanged with metal ions other than Fe varied in neither shape nor intensity with the type of metal ion (Fig. S3). Together, these results show that the acid properties of FER were not affected by the ion-exchange with metal ions. Py-FTIR spectrum of FER(18) was very similar with that of Fe-FER(18) (Fig. S4). The amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were calculated to be 330 and 78 μmol g−1 for FER(18), and 313 and 87 μmol g−1 for Fe-FER(18), respectively. This result also suggests that Fe-loading had little influence on the acid properties of FER. To summarize the characterization of the metal-loaded FER catalysts, the micropore structure and acid property of the FER zeolites were left mostly unchanged by ion exchange with metal ions. The implication is that the ion-exchanged metal ions themselves contribute to the skeletal isomerization of normal butene. Three main reaction mechanisms have been proposed for the skeletal isomerization of normal butene: the bimolecular reaction pathway, monomolecular reaction pathway, and pseudo-monomolecular reaction pathway [35,41,42]. In the bimolecular reaction mechanism, two normal butene molecules dimerize to form octene, and they undergo isomerization and cracking to form isobutene (Scheme S1A). However, cracking of octene produces not only isobutene but also normal-butene, propene and pentene. Thus, it is hard to produce isobutene with high selectivity with this reaction mechanism. In contrast, the monomolecular reaction mechanism can produce isobutene with high selectivity; however, the reaction rate is typically low because the reaction proceeds via formation of an unfavorable primary isobutyl carbenium ion (Scheme S1B). The pseudo-monomolecular reaction mechanism is assisted by protonated carbonaceous deposits formed during the reaction (Scheme S1C). This reaction pathway can avoid the formation of the unfavorable primary carbenium ion, and thereby the reaction rate becomes much faster than that of the monomolecular one. It is generally believed that the reaction proceeds via the pseudo-monomolecular reaction pathway when the amounts of carbonaceous species accumulated on the catalyst surface increase with increasing reaction time, and isobutene selectivity also increases accordingly. In the skeletal isomerization of 1-butene over FER(51), Fe-loading increased the isobutene selectivity by a factor of two without increasing the selectivity of by-products such as propene and pentene, suggesting that the reaction did not proceed via the bimolecular reaction mechanism (Table S2). However, the isobutene selectivity over Fe-FER(51) did not increase with increasing reaction time (Fig. 2B), suggesting that the reaction also did not proceed via the pseudo-monomolecular reaction mechanism under our reaction conditions (300 °C and 0.1 MPa). We also carried out the skeletal isomerization of 1-butene at 300 °C for 12 h using Fe-FER(51) (Fig. S5). However, isobutene selectivity monotonically decreased with increasing reaction time. This result supports that the formation of carbonaceous deposits contributing to the stabilization of reaction intermediates is slow over Fe-FER(51) at 300 °C and the reaction does not proceed via the pseudo-monomolecular reaction pathway under our reaction conditions. The thermogravimetry curve of the Fe-FER(51) catalyst after reaction showed that two types of coke (coke-type I and II) were formed during the skeletal isomerization of 1-butene at 300 °C (Fig. S6). The coke-type I (low-temperature coke at 210–420 °C) is composed of long chain oligomers formed on the acid sites inside the zeolite channel, whereas the coke-type II (high temperature coke at >420 °C) consists of methyl substituted aromatics or slightly condensed aromatics containing two to four aromatic rings [42]. The amount of coke-type II (5.5 %) was much larger than that of coke-type I (0.6 %) in our sample. It is generally accepted that the deposition of coke-type II on the external surface of zeolite blocks the inlet of the pore mouth and results in the deactivation of FER catalysts [28]. Thus, we propose that the skeletal isomerization of normal butene over Fe-FER proceeds via the monomolecular reaction mechanism, and that ion-exchanged Fe ions contribute to the stabilization of a primary isobutyl carbenium ion intermediate and thereby accelerate the reaction (Scheme S1B). However, when the activation energy for the skeletal isomerization of 1-butene was calculated from the isobutene production rate at 200–300 °C, the value for Fe-FER(51) (81 kJ mol−1) was similar to that of FER(51) (76 kJ mol−1) (Fig. S7). This indicates that ion-exchange with Fe ions does not change the quality of the active sites for skeletal isomerization of normal butene but rather increases the number of active sites. Wang et al. have reported that ion-exchange of FER zeolite with Ca ions greatly improves product selectivity and catalyst durability for the catalytic cracking of normal octene [46]. They also reported that structural analysis using powder XRD revealed that Ca ions were located at the center of an 8-MR channel near the intersection of 8-MR and 10-MR channels, ultimately concluding that Ca ions in this position must block the 8-MR channels, prevent the diffusion of molecules between the 8-MR and 10-MR channels and thereby suppress the successive reaction and coke formation, resulting in improvement of product selectivity and catalyst lifetime. Applying this reasoning to the present catalysts suggests that similar positive effects may be obtained by ion-exchange of FER. It is generally accepted that skeletal isomerization of normal butene over FER zeolite proceeds inside and/or near the pore mouth of the 10-MR channels [29,36,37,41]. We propose that ion-exchanged metal ions may restrict the diffusion of reactants and products in the micropores, prevent the occurrence of unfavorable side reactions in the micropores, and thereby increase isobutene selectivity and catalyst lifetime. The amounts and sites of the ion-exchanged metal ions varied depending on the type of metal ions, which may influence the catalytic activity of metal-loaded FER catalysts. 3.3 Effects of reaction conditions on isobutene selectivity and yield First, Fe-FER(51) was used as the isomerization catalyst, and the weight ratio of Ni-SA to Fe-FER(51) was varied from 0.50 g/0.00 g to 0.00 g/0.50 g. The reaction temperature was 300 °C, and the flow rates of C2H4 and N2 were both fixed at 20 mL min−1. The results are shown in Fig. 4 and Table S5. Isobutene selectivity was highest when Ni-SA and Fe-FER(51) were loaded at 0.25 g each. When the amount of Ni-SA was large and that of Fe-FER was small, some of the normal butene produced over the Ni-SA was skeletal isomerized over the Fe-FER to isobutene. However, the majority of normal butene passed over the Fe-FER without reacting, resulting in low isobutene selectivity. The isobutene selectivity increased with increasing amount of Fe-FER(51) until 0.25 g and decreased thereafter, indicating that side reactions such as the coupling of ethene and butene to form hexene, dimerization of butene to octene, and the successive cracking of octene were promoted when the amount of Fe-FER(51) catalyst was too large. Thus, overall, the highest isobutene selectivity was obtained at a Ni-SA/Fe-FER(51) weight ratio of 1. Isobutene yield was greatest at the Ni-SA/Fe-FER(51) weight ratio of 0.30 g/0.20 g, indicating that for efficient production of isobutene, it is important to equally promote ethene dimerization and the skeletal isomerization of normal butene. Next, the Ni-SA/Fe-FER(51) weight ratio was fixed at 1, and the conversion of ethene to isobutene was performed at 300 °C. The individual catalyst amounts were increased from 0.10 to 0.50 g each. The flow rates of C2H4 and N2 were both fixed at 20 mL min−1. Thus, the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was changed from 12,000 to 2400 mL g−1 h−1. The results are shown in Fig. 5 and Table S6. Ethene conversion and isobutene yield increased with increasing total catalyst amount (i.e., decreasing GHSV). This result is reasonable because the contact time of reactants and catalysts is longer with increasing amount of catalyst. However, isobutene selectivity first increased with increasing amount of catalyst until 0.25 g and then decreased thereafter. When the contact time was short, ethene dimerization predominantly proceeded over Ni-SA to form normal butene with high selectivity. However, at a short contact time, the skeletal isomerization of normal butene over Fe-FER(51) was slow, resulting in little formation of isobutene. Thus, isobutene selectivity was low when the amount of the individual catalysts was small. In contrast, when the contact time was too long, not only ethene dimerization but also trimerization and tetramerization of ethene proceeded on Ni-SA to form a mixture of butene, hexene, and octene, resulting in a decrease of butene selectivity. Furthermore, at long contact times, side reactions such as butene oligomerization and the successive cracking of oligomerization products were promoted on the acid sites of the SiO2-Al2O3 support and FER zeolite, resulting in an increase of the selectivity for long-chain hydrocarbons and hydrocarbons with odd carbon numbers. Thus, to optimize the isobutene selectivity, it is important to use only a moderate amount of the individual catalysts. At the optimum contact time, ethene dimerization and the successive skeletal isomerization of normal butene proceed selectively to give high isobutene selectivity. The effects of reaction temperature were also examined. Reactions were performed using Ni-SA (0.25 g) and Fe-FER(51) (0.25 g) in a flowing mixture of C2H4 (20 mL min−1) and N2 (20 mL min−1), with the reaction temperature varied in the range of 260–320 °C. The results are shown in Fig. 6 and Table S7. Ethene conversion and isobutene yield increased with increasing reaction temperature. However, while isobutene selectivity increased until 300 °C, it decreased thereafter. At temperatures greater than 300 °C, the selectivities for trans-2-butene and isobutene decreased, but those of C3, C5, and C7 + compounds increased with increasing reaction temperature (Table S7). Over the combination of catalysts, not only ethene dimerization and skeletal isomerization of normal butene but also side reactions such as butene dimerization and the successive cracking reaction of dimerization products proceeded, as already described. Thus, we speculate that at temperatures ≥ 300 °C, the rates of these side reactions are faster than that of skeletal isomerization of normal butene, resulting in a decrease of isobutene selectivity. Taking together the data presented in Figs. 4–6 and Tables S5–S7, the best reaction conditions with our setup were 300 ℃, 0.1 MPa, 0.25 g of Ni-SA, 0.25 g of Fe-FER(51), 20 mL min−1 of C2H4, and 20 mL min−1 of N2. Under these conditions, ethene conversion, isobutene selectivity, and isobutene yield were 35 %, 31 %, and 10.9 %, respectively. The isobutene selectivity obtained with this combination of catalysts was much higher than that of previously reported catalysts for ethene dimerization (Table 1). However, the isobutene yield was much lower than the equilibrium value of ethene dimerization (60.6 %). Further studies to examine methods to control the acid properties of Ni-SA and Fe-FER, and to clarify the roles of ion-exchanged metal ions, are ongoing in our laboratory to further optimize the production of isobutene from ethene. 4 Conclusions To produce isobutene directly from ethene, we combined an ethene dimerization catalyst with a catalyst for skeletal isomerization of normal butene. NiO/SiO2-Al2O3 (Ni-SA) was used as the ethene dimerization catalyst, and various zeolites with different crystal phases and SiO2/Al2O3 ratios were tested as the isomerization catalyst. The two types of catalyst were loaded into a fixed-bed flow reactor in separate phases, and ethene was converted into isobutene via normal butene. The Ni-SA catalyst alone was poorly active for isobutene synthesis, but loading zeolite downstream of the Ni-SA markedly enhanced the isobutene selectivity. To further improve the isobutene selectivity, we found that it was important to promote the skeletal isomerization of normal butene while also suppressing side reactions such as dimerization of butene and successive cracking of octene. Thus, the type of zeolite and the reaction conditions had marked influences on the isobutene selectivity. FER zeolite with a moderate amount of acid sites was the most effective for isobutene synthesis. Ion-exchange of FER zeolite with metal ions such as Fe and Cr ions further improved the isobutene selectivity and catalyst durability. Under the best reaction conditions (300 ℃, 0.1 MPa, 0.25 g of Ni-SA, 0.25 g of Fe-FER [SiO2/Al2O3 = 51], 20 mL min−1 of C2H4, and 20 mL min−1 of N2), ethene conversion, isobutene selectivity, and isobutene yield were 35 %, 31 %, and 10.9 %, respectively, which were much higher than those afforded by the conventional catalysts for ethene dimerization. Although further improvement of product selectivity and catalyst durability are necessary, the conversion of ethene to isobutene by combining catalysts for ethene dimerization and skeletal isomerization of normal butene is a promising alternative approach for isobutene synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Direct conversion of ethene to isobutene was studied by combining heterogeneous catalysts for ethene dimerization and skeletal isomerization of normal butene. NiO/SiO2-Al2O3 and zeolite were simultaneously loaded to a flow reactor in separate layers, and the conversion of ethene was performed at 300 ℃. Reaction using NiO/SiO2-Al2O3 alone produced normal butene predominantly, and isobutene selectivity was low at 1 %. However, introduction of zeolite into the lower catalyst phase greatly enhanced isobutene selectivity. The crystal structure and SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of zeolite had marked influences on isobutene selectivity, and ferrierite with a moderate amount of acid sites was most effective. The activity of ferrierite was further increased by ion-exchange with metal ions such as Fe, which enhanced not only isobutene selectivity but also catalyst durability. Effects of the reaction conditions were also studied, with the optimal setup affording isobutene at a selectivity of 31 %, which is the highest selectivity reported to date.
